intro: Mentha divergens, commonly known as the narrow-leaved mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often slightly hairy. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers in whorled clusters, which bloom from late spring to early autumn. Mentha divergens is a member of the Lamiaceae family, known for its aromatic properties and medicinal uses. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and woodland edges.
